entry.title: Configuring Web Assistant - Opening Documents from Trainer View of a Simulation
entry.content:
Good day,

Is there a way to configure our Fiori Launchpad plug-in so that when a simulation is clicked in the SAP Companion help panel, the trainer opens and offers the user the opportunity to open the simulation in any of the available modes (e.g. demo, practice, test, concurrent) OR the content generated from that simulation (e.g. a Word or PDF document)?

 

1. Context relevant simulation is selected from the help panel. 

 

As-Is Behaviour: Simulation opens in configured start mode (concurrent in our case).

 

Desired Behaviour: Trainer opens with links to simulation in all available modes and documents generated from that simulation. 

 

Our FLP plug-in was configured to open simulations in the concurrent mode by setting the learningAppProjectMode parameter equal to "praxis".  Help documents were embedded in media objects and assigned their own context so they could be opened directly from the help panel.

 

Now, we would like to try and avoid the additional LOE and offer our users a full view of the help available for a process with a single click via the trainer. (similar to what they see when clicking a simulation in the Learning library) . We tried removing the learningAppProjectMode parameter from the plug-in altogether but the sim still opens in practice mode (Web Assistantâ€™s default playback mode we suspect).

 

Any help with this would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Understanding HANA memory related license utilization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Dear Ada @f89322 ,

the size of the attachment will have an impact on the upload speed, but beyond that, the number and size of attachments does not impact the S/4 business processes, as the attachments are stored outside S/4.
When using the SAP managed scenario (default), there is no limit in terms of no. of attachments stored. For sure this only holds true for storing attachments related to the business context. The BTP DMS should not be kind of misused to upload e.g. holiday videos. ðŸ˜‰
In case you decide to use an external attachment storage via SAP_COM_0597, then you need to pay based on the size of attachments and by API calls.
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/fe051b8031274f919dae94150971c621.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

entry.title: Whatâ€™s New for the SAP Fieldglass and SAP BTP SBPA Integration
entry.content:
The 2025.11 release brought further enhancements to the integration between SAP Fieldglass and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA). This integration allows Configuration Manager users to customize approval, and now workflow logic with a self-service, no-code solution.

Whatâ€™s New for the SAP Fieldglass and SAP BTP SBPA Integration:

  • BTP Business Rules Payload Configuration Enhancements

The BTP Business Rules Payload Configuration interface has been enhanced to support front-end validation with a new business rule type: Workflow.  This option improves the accuracy and flexibility of rule setup by allowing users to validate both native SAP Fieldglass fields and Custom Fields based on the chosen business logic.

When submitting a Job Posting, users now select External Validation and will receive a Success, Warning, or Error message depending on the Decision Table setup in SBPA.

  • Enhanced Custom Field Support for BTP Integration

The Base Module in the BTP Business Rules Payload tile in SAP Fieldglass already supports Custom Fields and Linked Modules. With the 2025.11 release, there is now the capability to include all Linked Module Custom Fields. Extending this capability to all transactional child modules aligns the system to the business needs by leveraging Custom Fields across all relevant modules.

  • Previous Revision Supported in BTP Business Rules Payload

A Previous Revision section has been added to the configuration interface in SAP Fieldglass to allow comparison between current and previous document revisions in approval logic. This eliminates unnecessary approvals, accelerates document processing, and reduces manual intervention.

Want to Learn More?

  • The SAP Fieldglass and SAP BTP SBPA Approval Integration video shows step-by-step how to setup the integration between SAP Fieldglass and SAP BTP SBPA.
  • Watch the new Integrating SAP Fieldglass with SAP BTP SBPA for Workflow On-Page Validations video for a detailed overview of the new Workflow business rule type.
  • Explore the Integrating SAP Fieldglass with SAP BTP SBPA Guide for more information on the benefits, workflows, use cases, and links to additional enablement resources.

entry.title: The Managerâ€™s Guide to a Successful Performance Cycle
entry.content:
A great performance cycle isnâ€™t just about filling formsâ€”itâ€™s about creating clarity, accountability, and growth. Based on the HR Business Practices, one of the key assets of the SAP SuccessFactors process library, here are the essential actions managers should take at each stage of the cycle.

  • Setting Goals
  • Translate business strategy into team and individual goals aligned with corporate objectives.
  • Explain how performance outcomes influence rewards and opportunities.
  • Set goals and attributes according to the defined cycle and rating logic.
  • Continuous Updates
  • Keep goals, reviews, and development actions current and evidence-based.
  • Hold regular check-ins and coaching conversations focused on progress and support.
  • Provide timely, specific feedback linked to goals and attributes.
  • Encourage employees to request feedback and capture achievements.
  • Use self-service tools to document goals, feedback, and progress throughout the year.
  • Adjust goals and workload based on continuous insights.
  • Performance Review
  • Use formal reviews to summarize ongoing dialogueâ€”not start from scratch.
  • Prepare evidence-based performance cases ahead of calibration.
  • Seek HR support only for exceptions or complex situations.
  • Calibration
  • Participate actively in calibration sessions and be open to challenge and adjustment.
  • Apply agreed calibration outcomes consistently in reward and talent decisions.
  • Share feedback on calibration formats with HR.
  • Follow-Up Actions
  • Communicate decisions and next steps clearly and fairly to employees.
  • Provide feedback to HR on where the process supports or hinders real performance dialogue.

Why It Matters:
Managers are the driving force behind performance success. By following these recommendations, you turn the performance cycle into a strategic advantage for your team and the business.

Coming Soon:
Stay tuned! A new version of the HR Business Practices will soon be available. Check out this page for deeper insights into HR functions and how they support organizations in driving success.

entry.title: You Are Standing in an Open Field... Inside SAP GUI
entry.content:
How I ported Zork to ABAP in one day and made 46-year reunion of two mainframe legends possible.

1979 was quite a year for the mainframe: In Germany, SAP released R/2, the integrated ERP system that would define enterprise computing. In Massachusetts, Infocom was founded to commercialize Zork, the text adventure born on MIT's PDP-10 mainframes.

For 46 years, they ran on parallel tracks. Until last month.

Microsoft released the original source code for Zork I. The stars aligned. It was time for a family reunion.

I got nostalgic. I wanted to play Zork I: The Great Underground Empire. But I didn't want to play it in a browser or a terminal. I wanted to play it where I spend my time: In SAP GUI.

So, I decided to port the Z-Machine (Infocom's Virtual Machine) into SAP S/4HANA.

The Z-Namespace destiny... you knew it. In SAP development, every custom object must start with the letter Z: (Also Y, but Y is not used widely. And no one knows why Y is not used)

  • The Machine: Z-Machine.
  • The Transaction: ZORK.
  • The Package: $ZORK.

So it felt like it was meant to be here.

Building a VM in One Day (The "How")

"Alice," you say, "Writing a Virtual Machine in ABAP takes weeks of reading bit-level specs."

It took one day.

And I wrote almost none of it:

 
ZORK T-CODE in SAP GUI

99% Vibe coded

I used VSP (Vibing-Steampunk) â€” my open-source bridge that gives Claude (or Copilot/Codex/Mistral Vibe - any other Assistant) direct access to the SAP system via MCP. I treated the AI not as a chatbot, but as a Senior ABAP Developer who loves retro specs.

Here is what happened when my Z-Machine crashed on the first turn:

Me: "It crashes when I try to LOOK. Plz debug."

Claude didn't guess. Using VSP, Claude:

 

  1. Set a breakpoint in the ABAP code.
  2. Ran the game inside SAP.
  3. Inspected the memory (finding a Big-Endian vs Little-Endian mismatch in the object table).
  4. Fixed the code.

 

This isn't just generating text. This is Digital Archaeology assisted by Artificial Intelligence.

Why This Matters

I now have Zork running in S/4HANA.

But the real story isn't the game. It's the capability.

If an AI agent can read a 1980s technical spec, navigate a custom ABAP stack, and debug runtime errors to reunite two pieces of 1979 history...

...imagine what it can do for your 2005 legacy code ^_^ (Yes, even with ECC).

  • The Repo (ZORK-ABAP): https://github.com/oisee/zork-abap
  • The Tool (VSP): https://github.com/oisee/vibing-steampunk - ADT-to-MCP bridge.

Credits:

  • Infocom (1979) for the Z-Machine.
  • SAP (1979) for the R/2 legacy that led us here.
  • Graham Nelson for the Z-Machine Standards Document.
  • Claude (2025) for writing the code.

P.S. West of House. There is a transport request here.

#SAP #ABAP #Zork #RetroGaming #AI #MCP #DigitalArchaeology #OpenSource #Microsoft

Shout out to Scott Hanselman: Tnx for driving Open Source initiative ^_^

entry.title: Re: Clear down payment at the time of billing in S/4HANA...
entry.content:
To clear an open incoming payment which was not automatically closed, the app Clear Incoming Payments can be used to clear a receivable payment manually, such as an open incoming payment for a customer invoice. The system usually clears these payments automatically. However, sometimes customer information is missing, and the system cannot find appropriate open items that match the payment.

You can find more information on this in the Help Documentation: Clear Incoming Payments | SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: Re: Issue with Unit of Measure Mapping in Document and Re...
entry.content:
Hello @JuanseVal 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references for more details.

Have a look at this Blog: eDocument Colombia Cloud Initial Configuration

1. Answer to question regarding how you should handle SAP UoMs like PI when DIAN has no direct piece code:

For you to send PI as such in the XML, it must be in the DIAN catalogue. Which means you need to, map PI to a valid DIAN unit code that represents a single unit. This is typically a generic unit code used i your DIAN list. This practically means:

  • You keep using PI in logistics and sales,
  • You should convert your PI to the DIAN generic unit code. Therefore, quantities in the XML will remain the same but the unit code will change.

Here is a reference for configuring Unit of Measure (UNIT_OF_MEASURE): https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/cb9131e59ba34741923bd19ef4cb1f90/c8b16ee10e194b2880600db594a1e1c9.html?locale=en-US

2. Answer to your question regarding the availability of an SAP standard mapping table for Colombia:

To my knowledge no such mapping of SAP UoM Ã  DIAN UoM exist. The documents provided only explain how you can configure Unit of Measure in the App. Reason is the diversity of customers with various business cases and conversions.

3. Answer to your question regarding the creation of custom mappings:

You can, infact you must create custom value mappings for your use case (Colombia). While it is standard that you maintain your own lines in UoM for Colombia, the constraint worth noting is that the external value must be a valid DIAN code. Else the validator will reject the XML. So, you have two real options:

  • Option A is to keep SAP UoM and map to the closest DIAN unit, where you keep PI and other units for logistics, map each internal unit to DIAN legal code and use material UOM for conversions.
  • Option B is to adapt your business units to DIAN units, where you change sales UoM in the material master to match DIAN codes. This reduces mapping complexity but has a bigger impact on your processes and reporting.

4. Finally, my recommendation and experience is to:

  • Use DIAN unit list
  • Map you operational units where the exact label does not exist
  • Make sure you use description field and product master text to keep things clear
  • And finally, only adapt materials UoMs if the difference is material for taxes or pricing.

What this basically confirms is that your idea of handling PI through value mapping is in line with the Colombian implementation as long as you choose DIAN legal code.

Find below some more useful links

Electronic Customer Invoices: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/88d44bce214447bcb7cbbdc03eb16aa1/e7876c954f804f83add892c5ab660a39.html?locale=en-US

3432505 - eDocument Colombia Cloud Troubleshooting Guide: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3432505

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Fiori Elements: Dialog and busy indicator issues with actions
entry.content:
CAP application with a Fiori Elements front-end:
I've setup an action which opens a dialog box and accepts 'inputText' as input.

     @CDS.odata.bindingParameter.name: 'worksOrder'
      @Common.SideEffects: { TargetProperties: ['to_SearchResults','to_SearchFeedback','to_WorksOrderItems']}
      @ui.OperationAvailable: true
      @ui.Importance: #High
      @ui.OperationGrouping: #ChangeSet
      action getSearchResults(
        worksOrder: $self,
        @Core.Required
        @Common.Label: 'Describe in your own words what part you are looking for?'
        @ui.MultiLineText : true
        inputText: String(100)
      ) returns Boolean;

This calls a method, which perform a number of await methods, and finally returns true, closing the dialog.

The issue is, the first time it's executed, the busy indicator shows, and disables the dialog so it can't be closed. After the first time, the dialog is active (can be closed), but the busy indicator is now behind the the dialog, and can't be seen.

Ideally, the UI would be better if the dialog would auto-close, showing the busy indicator until the method has completed, in all cases. I don't want to return out of the action method early, as I have side-effects setup which means I need to manually refresh the data after the call.

Does anyone have a solution for this?

entry.title: Re: Identity Provisioning Service(IPS)-Assigning Custom Attributes to IAS Users with Transformation
entry.content:
@antoniobkw the following code worked for us to add SuccessFactors custom attribute 2. In our case, we needed to split users into SSO vs Password login based on whether they were Salaried or Hourly respectively. Therefore our Custom 11 field, which holds the Employment Type in SF is brought over to IAS like this:

{
"sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:successfactors:2.0:User']['custom11']",
"optional": true,
"targetPath": "$['urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:User']['attributes'][1]['value']"
},
{
"condition": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:successfactors:2.0:User']['custom11'] EMPTY false",
"constant": "customAttribute2",
"targetPath": "$['urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:User']['attributes'][1]['name']"
},

Further on in the Target Transformation, the following code was added to assign them to the SSO group ID in IAS:

{
"condition": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:successfactors:2.0:User']['custom11'] == 'Salaried Exempt'",
"constant": [
{
"id": "0207511c-7f9a-4297-9807-xxxxx"
}
],
"targetVariable": "assignGroup"
},

entry.title: HANA-Powered AMDP CRUD Framework: A Complete Workflow from ADT Development to ABAP Execution
entry.content:
1.Introduction 

In modern SAP applications, performance-critical database operations can be executed directly in SAP HANA using AMDP (ABAP Managed Database Procedures). This approach allows complex CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations to be processed efficiently in HANA while keeping the ABAP code clean and maintainable. In this guide, we explain how to implement a full CRUD solution using an AMDP class (ZCRUD_PROCEDURE) and consume it from an ABAP report with Data Base object. 

By the end, you will understand: 

  • How to design an AMDP class for CRUD operations 
  • How to call AMDP methods from ABAP 
  • How to handle different modes: Read, Update, Create, Delete 
  • How to display results or messages to users 

2.Business Requirement 

A business user needs to manage order data stored in the custom table ZCDS_CRUD. The requirements include: 

  1. Read: Display existing records in display-only mode. 
  2. Update: Pre-fill existing records and allow editing of fields. 
  3. Create: Insert new records with input from the user. 
  4. Delete: Remove a record and display a success/failure message. 
  5. Performance: All operations should execute directly on HANA using AMDP for speed. 

To achieve this, we implement: 

  • An AMDP class containing HANA SQL Script logic for all CRUD operations. 
  • An ABAP report that interacts with the AMDP class and provides an interactive interface for users. 

3.Technical Components 

  • ABAP Class (AMDP): ZCRUD_PROCEDURE 
  • Interface: IF_AMDP_MARKER_HDB 
  • Methods: READ_DATA, READ_ALL_DATA, INSERT_DATA, UPDATE_DATA, DELETE_DATA 
  • SQLScript logic for CRUD directly on HANA 
  • ABAP Report: ZCRUD_REPORT_AMDP 
  • Selection screen for input fields and CRUD mode checkboxes 
  • Calls AMDP methods 
  • Handles display, editable fields, empty fields for creation, and delete confirmation 

4.Application Flow 

  1. User opens report ZCRUD_REPORT_AMDP. 
  2. User enters an Order Number (P_ORD) and optionally Item, UOM, Quantity. 
  3. User selects one or more operation modes: Read, Create, Update, Delete. 
  4. Report calls AMDP class methods depending on the selected mode. 
  • Read: 
  • Calls READ_DATA 
  • Displays record in display-only format 
  • Update: 
  • Calls READ_DATA to fetch record 
  • Prefills fields with existing data 
  • Updates using UPDATE_DATA 
  • Create: 
  • Uses empty or input fields to call INSERT_DATA 
  • Delete: 
  • Calls DELETE_DATA 
  • Displays success/failure message 

5.Key Logic Implementation 

5.1 AMDP Class Definition 

CLASS zcrud_procedure DEFINITION 
  PUBLIC 
  FINAL 
  CREATE PUBLIC. 
 
PUBLIC SECTION. 
  TYPES: tt_type TYPE TABLE OF zcds_crud. 
  INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb. 
 
  CLASS-METHODS read_data 
    IMPORTING VALUE(iv_order) TYPE zcds_crud-order_number 
    EXPORTING VALUE(it_data) TYPE tt_type. 
 
  CLASS-METHODS read_all_data 
    EXPORTING VALUE(it_data) TYPE tt_type. 
 
  CLASS-METHODS insert_data 
    IMPORTING VALUE(iv_order) TYPE zcds_crud-order_number 
              VALUE(iv_item)  TYPE zcds_crud-item_number 
              VALUE(iv_uom)   TYPE zcds_crud-uom 
              VALUE(iv_qty)   TYPE zcds_crud-quantity. 
 
  CLASS-METHODS update_data 
    IMPORTING VALUE(iv_order) TYPE zcds_crud-order_number 
              VALUE(iv_item)  TYPE zcds_crud-item_number 
              VALUE(iv_uom)   TYPE zcds_crud-uom 
              VALUE(iv_qty)   TYPE zcds_crud-quantity. 
 
  CLASS-METHODS delete_data 
    IMPORTING VALUE(iv_order) TYPE zcds_crud-order_number. 
 
ENDCLASS.

5.2 AMDP Method Implementations (SQL Script) 

CLASS zcrud_procedure IMPLEMENTATION. 
 
METHOD read_data BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
  FOR HDB 
  LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
  USING zcds_crud. 
 
  it_data = SELECT * FROM zcds_crud WHERE order_number = :iv_order; 
 
ENDMETHOD. 
 
METHOD read_all_data BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
  FOR HDB 
  LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
  USING zcds_crud. 
 
  it_data = SELECT * FROM zcds_crud; 
 
ENDMETHOD. 
 
METHOD insert_data BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
  FOR HDB 
  LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
  USING zcds_crud. 
 
  INSERT INTO zcds_crud (order_number, item_number, uom, quantity) 
  VALUES (:iv_order, :iv_item, :iv_uom, :iv_qty); 
 
ENDMETHOD. 
 
METHOD update_data BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
  FOR HDB 
  LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
  USING zcds_crud. 
 
  UPDATE zcds_crud 
  SET item_number = :iv_item, 
      uom         = :iv_uom, 
      quantity    = :iv_qty 
  WHERE order_number = :iv_order; 
 
ENDMETHOD. 
 
METHOD delete_data BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
  FOR HDB 
  LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
  USING zcds_crud. 
 
  DELETE FROM zcds_crud WHERE order_number = :iv_order; 
 
ENDMETHOD. 
 
ENDCLASS.

5.3 ABAP Report: Selection Screen 

REPORT zcrud_report_amdp. 
 
PARAMETERS: p_ord TYPE zcds_crud-order_number OBLIGATORY, 
            p_read  AS CHECKBOX DEFAULT abap_true, 
            p_crea  AS CHECKBOX, 
            p_upd   AS CHECKBOX, 
            p_del   AS CHECKBOX. 
 
PARAMETERS: p_item TYPE zcds_crud-item_number, 
            p_uom  TYPE zcds_crud-uom, 
            p_qty  TYPE zcds_crud-quantity. 
 
DATA: lt_data TYPE zcrud_procedure=>tt_type, 
      ls_data TYPE zcds_crud.

5.4 ABAP Report: Execution and CRUD Operations 

START-OF-SELECTION.

  CASE 'X'.
    WHEN rb_read.
      PERFORM read_data.
    WHEN rb_crt.
      PERFORM create_screen.
    WHEN rb_upd.
      PERFORM update_screen.
    WHEN rb_dlt.
      PERFORM delete_data.
  ENDCASE.


*-------------------------------------------------------------*
* READ MODE â€“ SHOW DATA IN ALV (Display Only)
*-------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM read_data.

  zcrud_procedure=>read_data(
    EXPORTING iv_order = p_ord
    IMPORTING it_data  = lt_data ).

  IF lt_data IS INITIAL.
    WRITE: / 'No record found'.
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.

  CALL SCREEN 100.

ENDFORM.


*-------------------------------------------------------------*
* CREATE MODE â€“ EMPTY ALV WITH HEADERS (Editable)
*-------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM create_screen.

  CLEAR lt_data.
  ls_data-order_number = p_ord.
  ls_data-item_number  = p_item.
  ls_data-uom          = p_uom.
  ls_data-quantity     = p_qty.

  TRY.
      zcrud_procedure=>insert_data(
        EXPORTING
          iv_order = ls_data-order_number
          iv_item  = ls_data-item_number
          iv_uom   = ls_data-uom
          iv_qty   = ls_data-quantity
      ).
*      WRITE: / 'Record created successfully.'.
      MESSAGE 'Record created successfully' TYPE 'S'.
    CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lx).
      WRITE: / 'Error creating record:', lx->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
  "Add empty row
*  APPEND INITIAL LINE TO lt_data.
  append ls_data to lt_data.

  CALL SCREEN 200.

ENDFORM.


*-------------------------------------------------------------*
* UPDATE MODE â€“ ORDER DISPLAY ONLY, OTHERS EDITABLE
*-------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM update_screen.

  IF rb_upd = abap_true.
  zcrud_procedure=>read_data(
    EXPORTING iv_order = p_ord
    IMPORTING it_data = lt_data
  ).

  IF lt_data IS INITIAL.
     MESSAGE: 'No record found for update' type 'S'.
  ELSE.
    ls_data = lt_data[ 1 ].
    " Editable mode: overwrite with screen input if provided
    IF p_item IS NOT INITIAL.
      ls_data-item_number = p_item.
    ENDIF.
    IF p_uom IS NOT INITIAL.
      ls_data-uom = p_uom.
    ENDIF.
    IF p_qty IS NOT INITIAL.
      ls_data-quantity = p_qty.
    ENDIF.

    TRY.
        zcrud_procedure=>update_data(
          EXPORTING
            iv_order = ls_data-order_number
            iv_item  = ls_data-item_number
            iv_uom   = ls_data-uom
            iv_qty   = ls_data-quantity
        ).
        MESSAGE 'Record updated successfully' TYPE 'S'.
      CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lxupd).
        MESSAGE 'Error updating record:' TYPE 'S'.
    ENDTRY.
  ENDIF.
ENDIF.

  CALL SCREEN 300.

ENDFORM.


*-------------------------------------------------------------*
* DELETE MODE
*-------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM delete_data.

  zcrud_procedure=>delete_data(
    EXPORTING iv_order = p_ord ).

  MESSAGE 'Record Deleted successfully' TYPE 'S'.

ENDFORM.


*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* SCREEN 100 â€“ READ MODE (DISPLAY ALV)
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE status_0100 OUTPUT.
  SET PF-STATUS 'SCREEN100'.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_cust
    EXPORTING container_name = 'CC_ALV'.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_alv
    EXPORTING i_parent = gr_cust.

  CALL METHOD gr_alv->set_table_for_first_display
    EXPORTING i_structure_name = 'ZCDS_CRUD'
    CHANGING  it_outtab        = lt_data.

ENDMODULE.




*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* SCREEN 200 â€“ CREATE MODE (Editable)
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE status_0200 OUTPUT.
  SET PF-STATUS 'SCREEN200'.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_cust
    EXPORTING container_name = 'CC_ALV'.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_alv
    EXPORTING i_parent = gr_cust.

  CALL METHOD gr_alv->set_table_for_first_display
    EXPORTING i_structure_name = 'ZCDS_CRUD'
              i_default   = 'X'
    CHANGING  it_outtab        = lt_data.

ENDMODULE.

MODULE user_command_0200 INPUT.

  case sy-ucomm.
    when 'BACK'.
      LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.

    ENDCASE.

  READ TABLE lt_data INTO ls_data INDEX 1.

  TRY.
      zcrud_procedure=>insert_data(
        EXPORTING
          iv_order = ls_data-order_number
          iv_item  = ls_data-item_number
          iv_uom   = ls_data-uom
          iv_qty   = ls_data-quantity ).
      MESSAGE 'Record Created Successfully' TYPE 'S'.
    CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lx).
      MESSAGE lx->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
  ENDTRY.

  LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.
ENDMODULE.


*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* SCREEN 300 â€“ UPDATE MODE (Order display only)
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE status_0300 OUTPUT.
  SET PF-STATUS 'SCREEN300'.

  DATA lt_fieldcat TYPE lvc_t_fcat.
  DATA ls_fcat     TYPE lvc_s_fcat.

  "ITEM/UOM/QTY editable
  LOOP AT lt_data INTO ls_data.
  ENDLOOP.

  "Build field catalog
  ls_fcat-fieldname = 'ORDER_NUMBER'.
  ls_fcat-scrtext_l = 'Order'.
  ls_fcat-edit      = ''.
  APPEND ls_fcat TO lt_fieldcat.

  CLEAR ls_fcat.
  ls_fcat-fieldname = 'ITEM_NUMBER'.
  ls_fcat-scrtext_l = 'Item'.
  ls_fcat-edit      = 'X'.
  APPEND ls_fcat TO lt_fieldcat.

  CLEAR ls_fcat.
  ls_fcat-fieldname = 'UOM'.
  ls_fcat-scrtext_l = 'UOM'.
  ls_fcat-edit      = 'X'.
  APPEND ls_fcat TO lt_fieldcat.

  CLEAR ls_fcat.
  ls_fcat-fieldname = 'QUANTITY'.
  ls_fcat-scrtext_l = 'Qty'.
  ls_fcat-edit      = 'X'.
  APPEND ls_fcat TO lt_fieldcat.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_cust
    EXPORTING container_name = 'CC_ALV'.

  CREATE OBJECT gr_alv
    EXPORTING i_parent = gr_cust.

  CALL METHOD gr_alv->set_table_for_first_display
    EXPORTING
      is_layout       = VALUE lvc_s_layo( )
    CHANGING
      it_outtab       = lt_data
      it_fieldcatalog = lt_fieldcat.

ENDMODULE.

MODULE user_command_0300 INPUT.

  case sy-ucomm.
    when 'BACK'.
      LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.

    ENDCASE.

  READ TABLE lt_data INTO ls_data INDEX 1.

  TRY.
      zcrud_procedure=>update_data(
        EXPORTING
          iv_order = ls_data-order_number
          iv_item  = ls_data-item_number
          iv_uom   = ls_data-uom
          iv_qty   = ls_data-quantity ).
      MESSAGE 'Record Updated Successfully' TYPE 'S'.
    CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lxupd).
      MESSAGE lxupd->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
  ENDTRY.

  LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.
ENDMODULE.
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&      Module  USER_COMMAND_0100  INPUT
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*       text
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
MODULE user_command_0100 INPUT.

  case sy-ucomm.
    when 'BACK'.
      LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.

    ENDCASE.

ENDMODULE.

7. CRUD Operation Outputs (Screenshots Section) 

7.1 READ Operation Output 

7.2 CREATE Operation Output 

 

 

7.3 UPDATE Operation Output 

 

 

7.4 DELETE Operation Output 

 

 

6. Conclusion 

This implementation demonstrates how to: 

  • Use AMDP classes to handle CRUD operations directly on HANA 
  • Separate data logic (AMDP) from presentation logic (ABAP report) 
  • Handle different CRUD modes efficiently 
  • Provide clear user messages for all operations 

This approach ensures performance, maintainability, and user-friendliness while working with SAP HANA and ABAP together, and it can be extended to other database-intensive operations following the same pattern.

entry.title: SAP CPQ - Make your beautiful Christmas Theme in your tenant
entry.content:
The holiday season is here, and what better way to spread festive cheer than by giving your SAP CPQ tenant a beautiful Christmas makeover? A themed interface not only adds a touch of joy but also creates a delightful experience for your users during this special time of year.

Why Customize Your SAP CPQ Theme?

SAP CPQ offers flexible branding options that allow you to personalize the look and feel of your tenant. By applying a Christmas theme, you can:

  • Enhance user engagement with a festive interface.
  • Reflect your companyâ€™s holiday spirit.
  • Create a memorable experience for customers and internal teams.

Steps to Create a Christmas Theme in SAP CPQ

1. Access Branding Settings

Navigate to Setup â†’ Administration â†’ UI Designâ†’Branding in your SAP CPQ tenant. This is where you can customize with your style sheet

/* --- Header Background Styling --- */
.christmas-theme {
    /* Set a dark background if desired, or keep original. */
    /* background-color: #0d1a26; */ 
    position: relative; /* Essential for positioning lights and snow */
    overflow: hidden; /* Important to keep snow/lights contained */
}

/* --- Christmas Lights Container --- */
.christmas-lights {
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    width: 100%;
    height: 20px; /* Adjust height for visibility */
    display: flex;
    justify-content: space-around; /* Distribute lights evenly */
    align-items: center;
    pointer-events: none; /* Allows clicks to pass through */
    z-index: 10; /* Make sure lights are on top of the header background */
}

/* --- Light Bulb Styling --- */
.light-bulb {
    width: 11px;
    height: 15px;
    border-radius: 50% / 80% 80% 20% 20%; /* Bulb shape */
    box-shadow: 0 0 5px rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.7);
    animation: blink 1s infinite alternate; /* Simple blinking animation */
    position: relative;
    margin: 0 5px; /* Spacing between bulbs */
}

/* Add a "wire" to the bulb */
.light-bulb::before {
    content: '';
    position: absolute;
    top: -5px; /* Position above the bulb */
    left: 50%;
    transform: translateX(-50%);
    width: 5px;
    height: 5px;
    background-color: #333; /* Dark color for the wire */
}

/* --- Color Variations and Light Glow --- */
.light-bulb.red {
    background-color: #ff0000;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #ff0000;
}
.light-bulb.green {
    background-color: #94BF31;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #94BF31;
    animation-delay: 0.3s; /* Offset for blinking effect */
}
.light-bulb.gold {
    background-color: #00ff34;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #00ff34;
    animation-delay: 0.6s; /* Offset for blinking effect */
}
.light-bulb.purple {
    background-color: #FF00FF;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #FF00FF;
    animation-delay: 0.6s; /* Offset for blinking effect */
}
.light-bulb.blue {
    background-color: #0000FF;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #0000FF;
    animation-delay: 0.6s; /* Offset for blinking effect */
}
.light-bulb.pink {
    background-color: #ff347b;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 3px #ff347b;
    animation-delay: 0.6s; /* Offset for blinking effect */
}

/* Blinking Animation */
@keyframes blink {
    from { opacity: 1; }
    to { opacity: 0.5; }
}

/* --- Snowfall Effect Container --- */
.snowfall-effect {
    position: absolute;
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    width: 100%;
    height: 100%;
    pointer-events: none;
    background-image: radial-gradient(white 1px, transparent 0),
                      radial-gradient(white 2px, transparent 0),
                      radial-gradient(white 3px, transparent 0);
    background-size: 50px 50px, 70px 70px, 90px 90px;
    animation: snowfall 10s linear infinite; /* Animation to move the snow down */
    z-index: 5; /* Below the lights */
}

/* Snowfall Animation */
@keyframes snowfall {
    from { background-position: 0 0, 0 0, 0 0; }
    to { background-position: 500px 500px, 500px 500px, 500px 500px; }
}

Navigate to Setupâ†’Administration â†’ UI Designâ†’Responsive Template in your SAP CPQ tenant. This is where you can customize with your knockoutJS template

@using WebSite.Controllers
<header role="banner">
    @*don't show header if user doesn't want menu (e.g. user came from mobile)*@
    <div id="headerContainer" class="row cald_header_bar hidden" data-bind="css: {'hidden': shouldHideMenu, 'wrap-when-landing-C4C': !landedFromC4C }">
        	<div class="row sap_header_bar flex flex-between">
            <div class="cald_header_section">
                <h1 class="cald_logo">@Translation.Get("MainMenu.MainHeading")</h1>
            </div>
            <div class="cald_header_section-right sap_header_section-right">
                <nav role="navigation" class="shellbar-navigation" aria-label="Primary Navigation">
                    <ul class="nav flex">
                        <li class="shellbar-navigation-item hidden" data-bind="css: { hidden : isElectronicallyGuestLoggedIn }"><a aria-label="@Translation.GetJS("quotation.ProposalMain.NewProject")" href="#" data-bind="click: createNewCart, tooltip: { title: '@Translation.GetJS("quotation.ProposalMain.NewProject")', placement: 'left', viewport: 'header' }" class="fiori3-create-new-quote-icon create-new-quote-icon nav-menu-icon"></a></li>
                        @Html.PartialWithNameAsComment("RecentlyVisitedObjects")
                        @Html.PartialWithNameAsComment("CartSummary", true)
                        <li id="cpq-companion" data-bind="css: { hidden : !isEnabledSapCompanionFunctionality }"><a aria-label="@Translation.GetJS("Header.Companion.Notifications")" href="#" data-bind="tooltip: { title: '@Translation.GetJS("Header.Companion.Notifications")', placement: 'left', viewport: 'header' }" class="nav-menu-icon cpq-notifications-icon-style"></a></li>
                        @*show user menu*@
                        @*Show user menu only if user is not guest user nor electronically signed guest user*@
                        @Html.PartialWithNameAsComment("UserMenu")
                    </ul>
                </nav>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div>
            <button type="button" class="navbar-toggle pull-left" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".navbar-collapse1">
                <span class="icon-bar"></span>
                <span class="icon-bar"></span>
                <span class="icon-bar"></span>
            </button>
        </div>
        <div class="visible-xs logo-container">
            <div class="cald_logo no-margin"></div>
        </div>
        <!-- /.navbar-collapse -->
    </div>
            <div class="christmas-lights">
                <div class="light-bulb red"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb green"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb blue"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb purple"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb gold"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb pink"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb red"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb green"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb gold"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb blue"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb purple"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb red"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb pink"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb green"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb gold"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb blue"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb purple"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb blue"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb red"></div>
                <div class="light-bulb pink"></div>
            </div>
        <div class="snowfall-effect"></div>    
    <div id="topMenuC4C" class="hidden" data-bind="css: { hidden : !landedFromC4C }">
        <ul>
            <li class="main-list-item hidden @(@ViewBag.CurrentPage == "Catalog" ? "active" : "")" data-bind="css: {'hidden': landedFromC4C && !isQuoteLoaded}">
                <a href="/Catalogue/CategoryTree.aspx" class="sap-icon full-width" data-bind="tooltip: { title: '@Translation.GetJS("View.ResponsiveLayout.Catalog")', placement: 'left', viewport: 'header' }">
                    
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="main-list-item" data-bind="css: { active: document.location.pathname == '/quotation/BulkValidation.aspx', 'hidden': !bulkValidationShow || useNewQuoteEngine }">
                <a href="/quotation/BulkValidation.aspx" class="sap-icon full-width" data-bind="tooltip: { title: '@Translation.GetJS("BulkValidation.Title")', placement: 'left', viewport: 'header' }">
                    
                </a>
            </li>
            <!-- ko if: isQuoteEnvironmentExists()-->
            @Html.PartialWithNameAsComment("CartSummary", false) @*don't show user menu*@
            <!-- /ko -->
            <li class="main-list-item">
                <a class="dropdown-toggle sap-icon full-width" data-toggle="dropdown" href="#" data-bind="tooltip: { title: '@Translation.GetJS("Menu.Setup")', placement: 'left', viewport: 'header' }"></a>
                <ul class="left slide-out-section dropdown-menu slide-down side-menu-expanded-section setup-menu-dropdown-c4c" role="menu">
                    <li class="hidden" data-bind="if: setupLinksVisibility.isSetupLinkVisible(), css: { hidden : !tryIsAdmin }">
                        <a href="/admin/AdminTransfer.aspx?Log=1">
                            @Translation.Get("Menu.Setup")
                        </a>
                    </li>
                    <li class="hidden" data-bind="if: setupLinksVisibility.isDevelopConsoleLinkVisible(), css: { hidden : !tryIsAdmin }">
                        <a href="/DeveloperConsole" target="_blank">
                            @Translation.Get("Menu.DeveloperConsole")
                        </a>
                    </li>
                    <li class="hidden" data-bind="click: clearSessionStorageOnButtonClick, css: { hidden : !tryIsAdmin }"><a href="/multiusers/UserPersonalizationPage.aspx">@Translation.Get("Default.master.UserPage")</a></li>
                    <li class="hidden" data-bind="css: { hidden : !tryIsAdmin }"><a href="/multiusers/QuoteLayout.aspx">@Translation.Get("multiusers.QuoteLayout")</a></li>
                    <li class="hidden" data-bind="if: setupLinksVisibility.isEventLogLinkVisible(), css: { hidden : !tryIsAdmin }">
                        <a href="/SetupSpa/developer-tools/event-log" target="_blank">@Translation.Get("xmlEventLog")</a>
                    </li>
                    <li class="hidden" data-bind="click: clearSessionStorageOnButtonClick, css: { hidden : tryIsAdmin }"><a href="/multiusers/UserPersonalizationPage.aspx">@Translation.Get("Default.master.UserPage")</a></li>
                    <li class="hidden" data-bind="css: { hidden : tryIsAdmin }"><a href="/multiusers/QuoteLayout.aspx">@Translation.Get("multiusers.QuoteLayout")</a></li>
                </ul>
            </li>

        </ul>
    </div>
</header>
<div id="sideMenuContainer" data-bind="visible: isInitialized, css: (!landedFromC4C ? '' : 'd-none')" style="display: none">
    @*Show standard menu only if user is not guest user nor electronically signed guest user*@
    <div class="nav hidden" role="navigation" aria-label="Sidemenu Navigation" data-bind="css: { hidden : isGuestUserLoggedIn || isElectronicallyGuestLoggedIn || shouldHideOptions }">
        <ul class="nav cpq-scroll">
            <li class="side-menu-main-icon clearfix full-width" data-bind="css: { active: document.location.pathname == '/quotation/LoadQuote.aspx' || document.location.pathname == '/QuoteList' }">
                <a id="sideMenuLoadQuoteLink" href="/quotation/LoadQuote.aspx" class="sap-icon full-width" aria-label="@Translation.Get("quotation.ProposalMain.Existing")" data-bind="click: clearSessionStorageOnButtonClick, tooltip: { title: '@Translation.Get("quotation.ProposalMain.Existing")', placement: 'right', viewport: '#sideMenuContainer' }">
                    
                    <span class="left slide-out-section side-menu-expanded-section">
                        <span class="expanded-sidemenu-item" data-bind="visible: isSideMenuExpanded()">@Translation.Get("quotation.ProposalMain.Existing")</span>
                    </span>
                </a>
            </li>
            <li class="side-menu-main-icon clearfix full-width bulk-validation-side-menu-main-icon hidden" data-bind="css: { active: document.location.pathname == '/quotation/BulkValidation.aspx', 'hidden' : !bulkValidationShow || useNewQuoteEngine }">
                <a href="/quotation/BulkValidation.aspx" class="sap-icon full-width" aria-label="@Translation.Get("BulkValidation.Title")" data-bind="tooltip: { title: '@Translation.Get("BulkValidation.Title")', placement: 'right', viewport: '#sideMenuContainer' }">
                    
                    <span class="left slide-out-section side-menu-expanded-section">
                        <span class="expanded-sidemenu-item bulk-validation-list-header" data-bind="visible: isSideMenuExpanded()">@Translation.Get("BulkValidation.Title")</span>
                    </span>
                </a>
            </li>
            @IF (AssetsController.HasVisibleColumns())
            {
                <!-- ko if: !useNewQuoteEngine -->
                    <li class="side-menu-main-icon clearfix full-width" data-bind="css: { active: document.location.pathname == '/Assets' }">
                        <a href="/Assets" class="sap-icon full-width" aria-label="@Translation.Get("quotation.Assets")" data-bind="tooltip: { title: '@Translation.Get("quotation.Assets")', placement: 'right', viewport: '#sideMenuContainer' }">
                            
                            <span class="left slide-out-section side-menu-expanded-section">
                                <span class="expanded-sidemenu-item" data-bind="visible: isSideMenuExpanded()">@Translation.Get("quotation.Assets")</span>
                            </span>
                        </a>
                    </li>
                <!-- /ko -->
            }
            <li class="side-menu-main-icon clearfix full-width @(@ViewBag.CurrentPage == "Catalog" ? "active" : "")">

                }
            }
        }
    });
</script>

entry.title: Re: Cash Management feature comparison: License types and...
entry.content:
Dear @byd,

Question 1

Scope Items = What functionality is switched on

In Public Cloud, Scope Items are the best-practice process building blocks you select during scoping in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC)

More details below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-q-a/how-do-i-know-if-sap-cash-management-is-activated/qaq-p/14123735

License Bundles (Finance Base / Premium) = What you paid for / are entitled to run

SAP commercial Finance Base and Finance Premium bundles are broad packages. Importantly, both bundles include cash, liquidity and working capital management at the package level Premium is all Base + additional capabilities

SAP also treats SAP S/4HANA Cloud for cash management as a separately licensable product capability/add-on that is provisioned in the tenant but requires entitlement

More details below:

https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/certification-compliance/sap-s-4hana-cloud--public-edition-cloud-security-assessment--csa.html

Summary:

  • Basic Cash Management is typically the core/basic scope items (BFA/BFB) that most customers can activate with core Finance
  • Full/advanced cash management is tied to advanced scope items (J77/J78) and specific advanced features that SAP flags as requiring the cash management add-on/license

 

Question 2

SAP scope items are 3 characters (often letters+digits), not always 3-digit

Basic Cash Management (core/basic scope):

  • BFA â€“ Basic Bank Account Management
  • BFB â€“ Basic Cash Operations

Public Cloud for Cash Management (full/advanced scope):

  • J77 â€“ Advanced Bank Account Management
  • J78 â€“ Advanced Cash Operations

Other scope items commonly associated with Cash Management scenarios:

  • 2O0 Bank Fee Management
  • 2U8 Intercompany Process for Cash Concentration
  • 34P Treasury Workstation Cash Integration
  • 3L5 Liquidity Planning
  • 1MV Cash Application Integration (automation/ML for matching)

More details below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-q-a/how-do-i-know-if-sap-cash-management-is-activated/qaq-p/14123735

SAP does not publish a universally reliable Finance Base exact scope item list mapping, because entitlement can depend on contract, add-ons, and activation. The most defensible mapping and what you can verify quickly in your tenant is:

  • Finance Base: you can usually activate BFA + BFB scopes
  • Finance Premium: includes everything in Base cash scope doesnâ€™t automatically change unless you also have the cash management add-on entitlement and activate J77/J78

Question 3

Basic Cash Management (core/basic scope):

  • Bank statement processing (import/manual), memo records, cash reports, cash tools
  • Cash reporting via apps like Cash Flow Analyzer / Cash Position Analysis as part of basic operations

Typical limitation example some Cash Flow Analyzer selection capabilities are restricted in basic scope SAP explicitly notes certain interval-selection combinations are only supported when Advanced Cash Management (J78) is active

 

 

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3285568

Public Cloud for Cash Management (full/advanced scope):

In Public Cloud 2508 Feature Scope Description, SAP describes advanced daily cash manager activities such as

  • Monitoring actual + forecast cash positions
  • Tracking cash flow items across invoices, payments, bank statements, memo records, etc.
  • Bank transfers (initiate + monitor, templates)
  • Cash pooling (create/remove pools for concentration)
  • Payment approvals (approve/reject outgoing payments)
  • Cash flow reconciliation (reconcile intraday memo vs forecast)

and in Liquidity Management, SAP lists Cash flow analysis and forecast with:

  • analysis of historical cash flows with dimensions
  • forecasting with flexible dimensions (bank, country/region, company code)
  • ML-supported liquidity item adjustment

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: 01 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Phase 0 Objectives
entry.content:
This blog will focus on SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Phase 0 Objectives. 

This will be a multi-part series covering each topic in detail in the SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation. The content is based on my experience leading multiple large-scale SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation projects over the past 10+ years.

Why are you doing Phase 0? 

Phase 0 in SAP SuccessFactorsHCM is the critical pre-implementation groundwork, a strategic readiness phase before the formal project implementation kickoff, focusing on business alignment, scope definition, data assessment, and implementation strategy (Transformation or As-is) to ensure project success, reduce risk, and build the business case. It's about defining what you're doing and why, aligning stakeholders, assessing current systems, and planning the Integration, data migration, and change management needed for a smooth transition to SuccessFactors HCM.

Phase 0 Objectives:

The list below covers the broader topics we handle in phase 0. It may vary by customer, but the objective is to ensure a clear strategy, ownership, and solution appropriate in place. 

Phase 0 Objectives Description and Responsibility Matrix:

Commonly asked questions on Phase 0 SAP SuccessFactors HCM:

Question 1: Is Phase 0 mandatory?

Answer: Phase 0 is not mandatory, but for complex transformation projects involving multiple countries, it is strongly recommended.

Question 2: Is Phase 0 Part of the implementation? 

Answer: Yes and NO. Some customers prefer to do so outside of implementation to scope the project correctly (Budget, Timelines, Deployment approach). Some customers choose to do it as part of the implementation. In both cases, the outcome is to achieve the objectives listed above. 

Question 3: Who leads Phase 0? 

Customer leads Phase 0, and the Implementation Partner (SI) brings SMEs. Some objectives are owned entirely by the customer, some are SI, and some are shared. 

Question 4: What is the format of  Phase 0 Deliverables? 

  1. Deliver Process Maps (Signavio, Lucidchart, Miro, etc.) for business process design.
  2. PPT - for Strategy documents
  3. Word document for detailed solution documents

Question 5: Does Phase 0 involve configuration work? 

Typically, no, but it depends on the phase duration. Sometimes, we can do an Iteration 0 configuration, which always helps. 

Question 6: What is the role of the customer in Phase 0?

The Customer Team (Business and IT) owns Phase 0 and ensures its objectives are achieved.

Question 7: What is the role of the SI in Phase 0?

Assist the customer in defining the deployment strategy, and provide expert-level advisory on business process design and solution design for the future state. Align customer goals and bring the right people with experience in similar projects.

entry.title: HANA Replication
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We are planning to upgrade the memory of our existing PERSON_NAME appliance and aim to minimize downtime throughout the process.

Currently, the HANA Database System Replication is configured from the Primary Node to the Secondary Node using Log Replay, and from the Secondary Node to the Tertiary Node. The upgrade strategy involves failing over from the Primary to the Secondary Node and upgrading the Primary Node first. During the upgrade, replication will continue with the Tertiary Node. After the upgrade is completed, we will initiate replication from the Secondary Node back to the Primary Node, establishing multi-node replication. Once replication is active, we will fail back to the Primary Node and reconfigure replication from the Primary to the Secondary and from the Primary to the Tertiary Node for multi-node replication. After replication is established, we will perform the Secondary Node memory upgrade, aiming to ensure continuous business operations with the Tertiary Node as a safeguard. Due to limited bandwidth, we do not want to maintain a full replica between the Primary Node and the Tertiary Node.

Please help us understand how to avoid a full replica rebuild when replication switches from the primary node to the tertiary node. Additionally, let us know how we can ensure that, during replication initialization, it will start with either a full replica or a delta update.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: HANA Replication
entry.content:
Hi,

Similar to the steps involved in updating the HANA version, you can use system replication to minimise downtime 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HANA_PLATFORM/4e9b18c116aa42fc84c7dbfd02111aba/ee3fd9a0c2e74733a74e4ad140fde60b.html

Regarding the full sync, you are starting off with multi-tier system replication and then changing to multi-target when you register Dr to primary instead of secondary.
That is fine but will involve a full sync of DR as it takes the data from primary to dr 
The persistence of DR will be incompatible with primary and it wont be able to just sync the delta as it was registered to secondary previously and now is being registered to the primary.

entry.title: How can we review costing variants (PYR1 actual costing) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public (Grow 2508)
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We are currently facing some issues in the production costing process in our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Grow, release 2508) system. The actual costs calculated for production orders appear incorrect, and as part of our analysis we are trying to verify every component that may influence the costing results.

During our review of production orders, we noticed that the system is using the actual costing variant PYR1 (and a planned costing variant as well). However, we have not been able to identify where in S/4HANA Cloud Public we can:

  • Display or review the definition of costing variants such as PYR1

  • Understand what parameters characterize this variant (valuation logic, costing type, date control, etc.)

  • Determine how these variants are assigned or used in production order costing

In SAP ECC, we used transaction OKKN to view costing variant configuration, but in S/4HANA Cloud Public, we cannot find an equivalent pointâ€”nor an app or configuration area that displays these predefined variants or their logic.

Our main questions are:

  1. Where can we review the definition of costing variants such as PYR1 in S/4HANA Cloud Public?

  2. Are these costing variants predefined and not editable, or is there a recommended app or configuration view to understand how they work?

  3. Which apps, configuration steps, or documentation should we refer to in order to troubleshoot issues related to production costing (planned and actual)?

Any guidance or references from SAP experts or the community would be extremely helpful, as understanding the costing variant setup is key to diagnosing our current production costing issues.

Thank you very much for your support!

entry.title: Re: How to implement AI-assisted Scenarios in Cloud ERP Private and how to solve common problems
entry.content:
@MioYasutake Thanks for the comment.

There is an important word in your comment '...and often requires model training...' , I highlight this word because it is correct that not all use cases require training. The one I referred to in this blog does not - there is no Machine Learning happening on my data here. The fact that a training appears in the deployment section, is merely a means to an end to be able to activate the scenario.

With respect to your other question (and I feel is more a ML vs AI question) where data is needed to train a model, I would recommend that you always activate a scenario in a non production environment first, to take its through its paces, learn from it, tweak it...and first judge if it indeed does what you want it to, and then provide your users, in production, a really polished, valuable product that ensures adoption - not just because it makes sense but because:

  • Some use cases offer personalization possibilities (either by allowing prompting on custom entities, or leveraging a BADI to further tailor an interaction)
  • With Machine Learning scenarios - you can often tweak the importance and weighing of certain fields over others 

I do however take your point that all customers do not necessarily have a test environment with X years or Y volumes of data. If you have it in production, then refresh a test environment with it first. If you do not have the data, then wait until you do.

entry.title: SAP HANA Cloud Free Tier shows â€œinstance already existsâ€ but no instance is visible
entry.content:
We are working in a Pay-As-You-Go SAP BTP partner account and initially created a test SAP CAP application connected to an SAP HANA Cloud database. After deleting this setup to start fresh, we encountered an HDI containerâ€“related error while creating a new CAP application. When checking the HANA Cloud section, no database instance was visible, but attempts to create a new HANA Cloud instance consistently fail with an error indicating that an instance already exists. We tried deleting and recreating the HANA Cloud service and even removed the entire subaccount, but the same error persists, suggesting a previously provisioned HANA instance is stuck or orphaned and still consuming quota, blocking further database setup.

Error:  BrokerError, Description: You may only create one SAP HANA Cloud Free Tier instance

Main Issue

While setting up a fresh SAP CAP application, I encountered an HDI container error. When checking SAP HANA Cloud, I noticed that no HANA Cloud instance was visible, even though the system behaves as if one already exists.

What I Tried (and Failed)

  • Create a new SAP HANA Cloud instance
    â†’ Failed with an error stating that only one instance is allowed (instance already exists)

  • Delete the HANA Cloud database and recreate everything
    â†’ Failed (same error persists)

  • Delete the entire SAP BTP subaccount and recreate everything
    â†’ Failed (same error still occurs)

Current Situation

It appears that an existing or orphaned HANA Cloud instance is still consuming quota, even though it is not visible or accessible, which is blocking further database setup and CAP development.

 

I would appreciate any guidance on how to clean up or reset this stuck SAP HANA Cloud instance so that we can proceed with database setup and continue CAP development.

entry.title: How to use Document Generation for Growth Portfolio Workflow Email Notifications
entry.content:
The Growth Portfolio in SAP SuccessFactors is rapidly becoming the central hub for employee capabilities, achievements, and development evidence. As more organizations adopt this feature, HR teams are looking for ways to bring structure, consistency, and governance into the associated workflowsâ€” especially when approvals or reviews are involved.

While the standard workflow notifications in SuccessFactors offer basic messaging and are more tailored towards Employee Central's event based messaging, customers want more personalised experience during skill validations in Growth Portfolio with richer formatting, dynamic tags, tailored guidance, localized content, and branding consistency. 

This is where Document Generation becomes a powerful, under-used enabler.

Why Use Document Generation for Workflow Notifications?

Although Document Generation is commonly associated with performance forms or employee documents, it also serves as a flexible tool for workflow-based communication. Using Document Generation templates, you can:

  • Craft highly formatted notification content
  • Insert dynamic placeholders (tokens) from employee data and workflow context
  • Provide tailored instructions for each step of the Growth Portfolio Validation Workflow
  • Add branding elements like logos, headings, and style profiles
  • Maintain versions and localization easily
  • Reduce manual follow-ups and inconsistencies

Document Generation essentially becomes your custom â€œemail content designerâ€â€”while the workflow notification still handles the delivery.

Step for Configuring Custom Email Notifications Using Document Generation

Step 1: Enable Document Generation (if not already enabled)

In Admin Center, confirm that Document Generation is active and that you have permission to create and manage document templates.

Step 2: Go to Document Generation - Manage Document Template

  1. Click on Create New and select Document Generation Group
  2. Fill the basic details like Group Id and description about this template
  3. Now, click on Create New and select Document Generation Template

     

  4. This is the place where we would design our email templates' Subject and content
      • First fill up the basic details as shown below and tailor it as per the specific requirement like Template Id, Name, description, Category=Workflow, Language and assign the Workflow group created in above steps
      • Now update the email Subject and email Content as required, refer below screenshot

     

    • The tokens are highlighted in yellow within double square brackets [[token]], you can use standard tokens or create your own tokens using 'Insert Token' option as shown below. Also there are other options to customize the text, colour, hyperlink etc,

       

Step 3: Now we need to map values to the tokens

  1. Go to Document Generation - Manage Document Template Mapping and select respective Template created in Step 2 above.
  2. It will look like this, here we select different mapping type to assign values to our tokens in the email message

    1.  

  3. Now select the appropriate mapping as shown below dropdown

     

  4. Below are different set of values I have selected, like Employee token is mapped to show only First Name of employee and other values are referenced from Workflow context

Step 4: Now we need to assign the different such workflow email template to specific workflow action/step

  1. Go to Manage Workflow Email Configuration, and click Create, then it shows below screen 

     

  2. Now fill the code and Name and also keep only those notifications enabled which are required

     

  3. Now select the template created above instead of 'Standard template' where applicable, here we select it for Initiator (employee) to get a tailored email as per requirement when manager approves the proficiency change request in Growth Portfolio (GP)
  4. Select and save this configuration 

Step 5: Assign this Workflow Email Configuration to actual Manager workflow used in Growth Portfolio Validation business rule

  1. Go to Manage Organization, Pay and Job Structures, select Workflow - Manager
    Reference business rule to identify the Worklfow

     

  2. Now update the Workflow Email config (from Step 4) as below and save

Step 6: Test, employee changes skill proficiency and manager approves, then below custom email is received by employee instead of standard template

As you notice above, employee Aanya received the customised email notification post skill proficiency change approved by Manager. Email Subject and Content got changed and tokens pulled specific data as per mapping setup highlighted in yellow.

Approved Workflow request to see the comments posted by Approver using the hyperlink in email

Below is the standard template of Workflow Email Notification as configured in Email notification template settings > Workflow Step Approved Notification and how currently it appears for TIH > Growth Portfolio validation workflows.

So as we saw that SAP SuccessFactorsâ€™ Document Generation tool is more than a document builderâ€”itâ€™s a strategic communication engine. By integrating it into the Growth Portfolio Validation Workflow, organizations can deliver clearer, richer, and more personalized email notifications that guide users through every step of the process.

Hope this helps you to support customers further in their journey of becoming a skill based organisation and better manage employee skills.

Please let me know in comments how further we can use Document Generation to generate more contextualised workflow notifications. Happy to discuss!

PS: Link to my previous blog on how to setup workflow in Growth Portfolio can be checked here .

entry.title: Low Code/No-Code Capability (LCNC) support in SSAM
entry.content:
Overview

For a product like SAP Service and Asset Manager, adaptability is a core expectation, but it must be delivered in a controlled and maintainable way. The LCNC feature introduces a configurable layer within SSAM that enables customers to adjust field behavior, visibility, validation rules, and simple logic through metadata-driven settings rather than custom development. By supporting LCNC within its intended scope, SSAM reinforces its position as a flexible, enterprise-grade platform that can adapt to evolving business needs while maintaining architectural stability and performance.

Changes needed for LCNC

1. Backend Configuration to enable LCNC

In the Mobile Application Configuration section in Configuration Panel, set the parameter â€˜enable.metadata.parsingâ€™ under the LCNC parameter group to â€˜Yâ€™ and mark the parameter as Active. This enables LCNC metadata processing in SSAM.

2. Additional Business Fields using OData Properties

SAP Service and Asset Manager allows you to expose additional business fields on the mobile detail screens by enabling properties from the underlying OData entity sets. These properties, including both standard SAP fields and custom Z-fields, can be configured in the backend without changing the standard metadata. Once enabled, they appear on the mobile client as separate lines within the detail view, giving users more relevant information.

2.1 Changing existing SAP delivered fields through LCNC

You can expose standard SAP properties that already exist in the OData entity sets but are not shown by default on the mobile detail or list screens. Enabling fields like Priority and Main Work Center gives technicians quick visibility into urgency and ownership information without navigating through multiple screens.

The following examples show how LCNC makes these fields available on the mobile app.

In the Configuration Panel, go to 'OData Model Configuration' and select 'MyWorkOrderHeader'. Navigate to the Property List tab, choose the 'Priority field, switch to Edit mode, and enable the 'Extension' options. We can also define attributes like 'Custom Label', 'Visible in List Screen', 'Visible in Detail Screen' and 'Searchable'.

Repeat the same steps for MainWorkCenter property in MyWorkOrderHeader.

Now after saving these changes and performing a clean sync in SSAM client, the Work Order List screen displays both â€˜Custom Main WorkCenterâ€™ and â€˜Custom Priorityâ€™.

 

Now go to WorkOrder detail screen and scroll down to the Details section to see that Custom WorkCenter and Custom Priority are displayed.

2.2 Adding custom Z-fields

If your backend includes custom Z-fields, SSAM can display them on the mobile client by enabling them in the OData model configuration.

Let us enable LCNC for an existing ZProperty called  ZAisaProperty and assign it a Custom label Aisa_lcnc_property. In this example we make the field 'Visible in the Detail Screen' and mark it as 'Searchable'

Now save these changes and perform a clean sync and you will see the updated Work Order List Screen. Next let us pick an order which is moved to Hold State (WO#  4021881) after making this change. This WO detail screen which will display â€˜Changed Byâ€™ field.

After status change, from WO list screen, locate the WO.

Now select the WO 4021881 to go to the WO Details screen. Scroll down to Details section and you can see Aisa_lcnc_property displayed.

entry.title: Unlocking the NPP: Payments overview
entry.content:
Welcome to the second installment of the Blog series on the New Payments Platform (â€œNPPâ€) in Australia.

The series is planned as:

  1. Unlocking the NPP: SAP Capabilities for Faster, Smarter Payments
  2. Unlocking the NPP: Payments overview
  3. Unlocking the NPP: PayID
  4. Unlocking the NPP: PayTo

In the previous Blog we described the capabilities of the NPP and provided a brief insight into how SAP delivers these.

In this Blog weâ€™re going to dive into some of the details around file formats and Bank integration as these underpin the process. As mentioned in the previous Blog, each Bank defines their file format and contents so you will need to check these when building your specific solution.

 

Payment Format basics

Iâ€™m going to assume a working knowledge of SAP Payment processes, formats and integration but some of the terminology warrants further explanation.

NPP is built around files or messages (and Iâ€™ll use the terms interchangeably) based upon ISO20022 which is:

â€œA single standardisation approach (methodology, process, repository) to be used by all financial standards initiativesâ€ and â€œa multi part International Standard prepared by ISO Technical Committee TC68 Financial Services. It describes a common platform for the development of messagesâ€.

https://www.iso20022.org/

For our purposes we just need to understand that ISO20022 defines numerous message types and their formats. The main message types SAP will be creating are the Payment Initiation (â€œpainâ€) formats:

  • pain.001 Customer Credit Transfer Initiation
    • this is the typical outgoing payment bank transfer
    • includes payments to BSB / Bank Account and to PayID (OSKO ID)
    • also support Direct Debits with PayTo Agreement
    • latest version V12 â€“ pain.001.001.12
  • pain.008 Customer Direct Debit Initiation
    • this is the request to collect from a Customerâ€™s bank account
    • includes collections from BSB / Bank Account and with PayTo Agreement
    • latest version V11 â€“ pain.008.001.11

 

SAP standard content

So what does this mean in SAP? We maintain payment file formats in the Data Medium Exchange Engine  â€“ in SAP ECC this is transaction DMEE, in S/4HANA we have DMEEX (Extended) whilst in Public Cloud we use app â€œCreate Payment Medium Formatsâ€. Iâ€™m not going to discuss the older RFFO* programs which required ABAP coding to manage the formats.

The payment file formats manage the file structure (header and item levels, field names and definitions etc) and the field contents. Contents can be hardcoded, mapped from SAP Payment structures (FPAY* tables) or flexibly derived through coding.

The ISO formats are delivered by SAP with a prefix CGI (Common Global Implementation) and you should see these in your S/4HANA system:

  • AU_CGI_XML_CT CGI                 Credit Transfer for Australia
    • This equates to the pain.001 format
  • AU_CGI_XML_DD CGI                Direct Debit for Australia
    • This equates to the pain.008 format

You may wonder why there is an Australian version of a global standard. One example is the use of the combination of BSB and Account number to manage Bank details for Payer and Payee, rather than just a single identifier such as an IBAN.

The latest published ISO pain.001 files version is 012 whilst the delivered SAP S/4HANA content is version 006. We are investigating when and how to release updated content for all file types. This is not an urgent requirement as Banks and NPP do not adopt the latest version immediately on release and updates can be configured as required.

In addition to the Australian versions of the ISO format, there are some generic formats delivered which may be useful as a reference:

  • S/4HANA
    • CGI_CT                CGI Credit Transfer
    • CGI_DD               CGI Direct Debit (Automatic Debit)
  • ECC (including Success Factors Employee Central Payroll)
    • CGI_XML_CT
    • CGI_XML_DD

 

Versions and Bank formats

In the previous Blog we described how SAP interacts with Banks who are connected to the NPP.

 

The Payerâ€™s SAP system will create a payment file in the format required by the Bank. This may be in older ISO format (or variant) or another format.

The Bank validates this within their internal system and creates a pacs.008 Customer Credit Transfer â€“ Clearing Request which is sent to the NPP to make the payment.

A quick review of the Big 4 Banksâ€™ publicly available information on file format and mapping shows:

  • 2 mention pain.001 version 03
  • 1 mention ABA / DE (BECS) format
  • 1 has no specific NPP information

Just sending a pain.001 ISO format file to the Bank does not automatically mean that it will be processed through the NPP rather than BECS. Each Bank may use different fields in the file to determine the processing channel (i.e. NPP or BECS) and these may entail use of existing â€œproprietaryâ€ (customer defined) fields. Banks can receive other formats, including NPP specific fields such as PayID (OSKO) and map the contents internally prior to sending to the NPP

The upshot of all this is that each SAP Customer will need to check with their Bank on formats, field content and data mapping to ensure files are processed correctly. Whilst there is a perception that everyone needs to move onto ISO20022 formats in readiness for the 2030 shutdown of the BECS clearing system, the timeframe is dictated by the Banks who determine their required format. 

As mentioned in the previous Blog, SAPâ€™s strategic direction is to provide solutions based on common standards but not the Bank specific variations. Customers will therefore always require some additional customization to adjust the delivered standard content.

 

SAP Bank Integration

NPP does not require any specific changes to Bank integration and the typical legacy point to point integration can be retained. However, SAP recommends Multi Bank Connectivity (â€œMBCâ€) combined with as the future state for NPP.

 

MBC already provides benefits around a managed integration service with visibility and control of the payments files. In the context of NPP itâ€™s worth bearing in mind that the volume and frequency of â€œtrafficâ€ to and from the Bank is likely to increase. Each Payment Header and Item will trigger three incoming messages (File accepted, Pending and Transaction Processed / Rejected). Customers may change the frequency of outgoing payments, for example moving from a batch driven weekly run to daily or even real-time activity. With the NPP operating 365 days a year, payments can be scheduled on weekends or Public Holidays. This allows payments exactly according to payment terms (but not early), enabling access to settlement discounts and improving cash flow. 

Similarly Incoming payments are usually only visible in the Bank Statement received the following day. As customers move to NPP for incoming payments and want to adopt flexible business models, such as processing sales or deliveries on receipt of funds, there is a requirement to handle real time incoming payment messages or intraday bank statements.

The combination of MBC and BCM provides a solution for bank integration suited to both real time processes and detailed logging of the inbound and outbound flows, as well as monitoring the status of payments and resolving errors.

MBC Member Banks can offer their APIs to SAP customers, enabling enhanced real-time capabilities while maintaining the security and reliability of the SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity platform. Some of the additional capabilities of the NPP such as PayTo Agreements (as the successor for Direct Debits) assume usage of APIs and sample files and flows are available from Australian Payments Plus (as the owner of NPP) as well as from Banks. Where a customer implements an API outside of MBC, they are responsible for all aspects of build and operation, including middleware, encryption and monitoring.

 

NPP payments â€“ the basics

Letâ€™s assume we are working with a Bank which requires the pain.001 Version 003 file with a couple of specific field mappings.

Firstly, you should create the Bank specific version as a Child Tree of the standard format in DMEEX.

 

This new Format can be edited as required to meet the Bank specific Version, Format and Mapping details.

For example, the Bank requires â€œ<PmtMtd>â€ as â€œTRFâ€ and â€œPmtTpInf><LclInstrm><Prtry>â€ as â€œX2PIâ€ for a file to be processed with NPP (OSKO). This can be achieved with simple use of Constant in the DMEEX configuration.

Other mapping is possible with an understanding of how the information flows into the standard Payment file structures â€“ refer this Blog and related note:

Source of Information for Field in structures FPAYH-FPAYHX-FPAYP

Further flexibility is possible using BAdI FBL_EVENT_06 which enables population of ZREF01-ZREF10 fields which can then be mapped to the DMEE fields.

The Payment Format needs to be assigned to the Payment Method.

 

You may consider defining new NPP specific Payment Methods. This is not mandatory but does provide a clear way to execute separate Payment Runs and Payment Files for BECS and NPP. For some Banks, the Payment Channel (NPP or BECS) is defined at the File header level.

You are also able to define whether the Payment Method can continue to work with BSB and Bank Account numbers from the Business Partner master or if PayID details are required (see next Blog).

The Payment Run execution, Payment File creation and transfer to the Bank follows the existing processes.

 

Incoming messages for payments

The Bank will send three status confirmation messages using the pain.002 format. How these are handled depends on your setup:

  • SAP BCM enables receipt and reporting of the incoming messages. This has integration back to the original payments and enables error handling through the reversal of the outgoing payment document and reset of open items, allowing a new payment to be created.
  • SAP MBC provides message viewing and forwarding capabilities
  • Custom built solution to store and view files as part of custom bank integration
  • No SAP solution, with potential to view in Bank portal
